title: 103_s2381
content: SECTION 1. HEALTH CARE FRAUD AND ABUSE GUIDANCE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services solicits proposals for modifications and new safe harbors annually, starting from January 1, 1995. The Secretary of Health and Human Services solicits proposals for modifications and new safe harbors annually, including payment practices that are not considered criminal offenses under the Social Security Act and special fraud alerts. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, will publish proposed modifications to existing safe harbors and new safe harbors in the Federal Register for a 60-day comment period. After considering public comments, final rules will be issued. The Inspector General will report annually to Congress on these matters. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, will publish proposed modifications to existing safe harbors and new safe harbors in the Federal Register for a 60-day comment period. The Inspector General shall report annually to Congress on the proposals received and the reasons for rejection of any proposals not included in the publication. The Secretary may consider various factors when modifying and establishing safe harbors, such as the impact on access to healthcare. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, will publish proposed modifications to existing safe harbors and new safe harbors in the Federal Register for a 60-day comment period. Factors considered include the impact on access to healthcare, quality of services, patient choice, competition among providers, and cost to Government programs. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, will publish proposed modifications to existing safe harbors and new safe harbors in the Federal Register for a 60-day comment period. Factors considered include financial benefits to healthcare professionals, preventing fraud and abuse in Government healthcare programs, and interpretive rulings by the Inspector General. The Inspector General, in consultation with the Attorney General, issues interpretive rulings in response to specific requests regarding the application of sections 1128A and 1128B of the Social Security Act. These rulings do not carry the force of law and are considered interpretive rules under section 553(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Inspector General issues interpretive rulings in response to specific requests regarding the application of sections 1128A and 1128B of the Social Security Act. Rulings are published in the Federal Register or made available for public inspection. If a ruling is not issued, the requesting party is notified with reasons for the decision. Criteria are considered when determining whether to issue an interpretive ruling. The Inspector General issues interpretive rulings in response to specific requests regarding the application of sections 1128A and 1128B of the Social Security Act. When considering a request, the Inspector General may assess if there is an ambiguity in the statute, safe harbors, or previous rulings, and if the request can be addressed by interpreting existing rules or would require a substantive ruling not authorized under this subsection. The Inspector General does not provide interpretive rulings on factual issues, including party intent or fair market value. Special fraud alerts can be requested at any time to inform the public of suspicious practices under the Social Security Act. The Inspector General investigates requests for special fraud alerts and may issue them in consultation with the Attorney General. Special fraud alerts are published in the Federal Register. Criteria for issuing special fraud alerts include considering the extent of suspicious practices. The Inspector General investigates requests for special fraud alerts in consultation with the Attorney General. Criteria for issuing special fraud alerts include assessing the potential consequences and frequency of suspicious practices.
